importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the latest development in the Mariners' postseason campaign.
The date of the Mariners' ALDS victory over the Yankees, which is historically significant as it is believed to have saved baseball in Seattle.
The date of the 2001 ALCS game in which Bret Boone hit a game-tying homer in the 8th inning, a pivotal moment in Mariners history and the last such homer in that format before Suárez’s.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current timeline of the playoff series, with Game 6 in Toronto scheduled for Sunday, highlighting the urgency and momentum of the Mariners' push toward the World Series.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, the second in Mariners postseason history, giving Seattle a 6-2 win over the Toronto Blue Jays.
This win moves the Mariners to a 3-2 series lead, just one win away from their first World Series appearance in franchise history.
The Mariners have never made it to the World Series despite multiple playoff appearances, making this milestone historically significant.
Suárez’s emotional postgame comments highlighted the personal and familial significance of the moment, especially in front of his daughters and wife.
Cal Raleigh’s home run in the eighth inning was the first such homer in a postseason game in that inning since 2001, and tied Aaron Judge’s record for most home runs in a single season in the AL.
The victory marks a turning point in the series after two dominant wins by the Blue Jays in Seattle, signaling a shift in momentum for the Mariners.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez hit a game-winning grand slam, a pivotal moment that brought the Mariners within one win of their first World Series appearance, marking a significant achievement in franchise history.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the subject of the article, with a historic playoff push that has them just one win away from their first World Series appearance in over two decades.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the playoff series, with their earlier wins in Seattle creating tension and setting the stage for the Mariners’ comeback.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller was removed from the game in the fifth inning, which allowed the Blue Jays to score and set up a key moment in the game’s progression.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh hit a critical game-tying home run in the eighth inning, marking a historic moment in Mariners postseason history and tying a major AL single-season record.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer scored a run in the fifth inning with a two-out double, contributing to the Mariners’ ability to stay in the game after a tough start.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement drove in a run in the sixth inning with a single, helping to maintain the Mariners’ momentum after earlier scoring efforts.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Barger was driven in by George Springer’s double in the fifth inning, contributing to the team’s scoring in a pivotal stretch of the game.

namedEntities.name: Alejando Kirk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kirk was driven in by Ernie Clement’s single in the sixth inning, adding to the Mariners’ scoring in a critical phase of the game.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Judge
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge holds the record for most home runs in a single AL season, and Cal Raleigh is now tied with him, making the achievement in the postseason historically notable.

namedEntities.name: Bret Boone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boone hit a game-tying homer in the 8th inning of the 2001 ALCS, the last such homer in that format before Suárez’s, showing a historical continuity in Mariners postseason drama.

namedEntities.name: Dan Wilson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wilson commented on the emotional impact of Suárez’s homer and the crowd’s reaction, highlighting the significance of the moment in Mariners history.

namedEntities.name: New York Yankees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Yankees are referenced in the historical context of the Mariners’ past playoff runs, specifically in the 1995 ALDS and 2001 ALCS, where the Mariners narrowly lost.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning to give the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays, moving the team to a 3-2 series lead and within one win of their first World Series appearance in franchise history. This marks a historic turning point, as the Mariners have never made it to the Fall Classic despite multiple playoff runs. Suárez’s performance, which occurred in front of his family and fans, was emotionally charged and symbolically significant. Cal Raleigh also contributed with a game-tying homer in the eighth inning, a rare feat in Mariners postseason history. The Mariners now face the Blue Jays in Game 6 in Toronto, with the team just one win away from achieving a milestone that would complete a long-standing legacy gap in their franchise history.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
